content:
Tim Abbott asked me to kick off a thread about the choice of "manage group" vs. "administer group" as the terminology for being able to change group data (name/description, permissions, membership).

In #25929, I used the term "manage group" because:

  • I wanted to avoid confusion between this and the administrator role.
  • It felt more natural to me.
  • It's also a term we use to label the "Manage streams" menu (which of course could be changed).

Starting this thread in case folks have other thoughts on this, though. It affects how we'll want to name variables in the codebase as well.
I like both names. I think "manage" is probably the better choice, but I found myself saying "administer" today in a similar context.

You mention "Manage streams", and I have always felt that that wording is not quite right, but I don't have a good alternative for that off the top of my head. It's also strange to be that it's above the other settings stuff.
Yeah "manage streams" is tough in that it's ambiguous whether you're administering the streams for everyone or for yourself; of course you can do both in the UI, so it's not necessarily bad.

manage as a verb is recognizable. Administer is a bit new. I would rather use "Admin something". I guess in russian manage is управление, while admin is конфигурирование/настройка - config and control?
